results.title: Australia's refugee dilemma
results.creator_credit: Neil Barrett, Video Education Australasia and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description: The United Nations definition of refugees: “People who are (1) outside their country of nationality or their usual country of residence, and (2) are unable or unwilling to return to that country due to a well-founded fear of being persecuted for reasons of race, religion, nationality, membership of a particular social group, or political opinion.” Australia takes in many refugees legally and illegally, from all over the world, but in recent times the majority of would be refugees, or asylum seekers, come from Iraq, Iran and Afghanistan and more often than not, have been smuggled across the seas in run-down fishing boats from Indonesia. In desperation, these asylum seekers are escaping from persecution either by the brutal regime of Saddam Hussein or the repressive rule of the Taliban and see Australia as the country which will offer them sanctuary, freedom of speech and religion. However, since September 2001, the Australian Government has passed legislation and the “Pacific Solution” to prevent asylum seekers reaching Australia - any that successfully reach our shores without the correct paperwork face mandatory detention. This program, with a 2002 update, combines television footage from ABC “Four corners” and “7.30 Report” including interviews with refugees, Philip Ruddock (Minister for Immigration) and John Olsen (the then Premier of South Australia) among others, with discussion on the situation of asylum seekers, legal and illegal, the rules for obtaining protection and temporary protection visas and the Australian Government’s position on this vexing and controversial issue. Suitable for Years 9-12 Secondary and Tertiary students. Teacher notes included
results.creator_credit_for_label: Neil Barrett, Video Education Australasia and ABC-TV (Australia)

results.title: Australia's one man zoo
results.brief_description: Promotional documentary on Melbourne’s Wildlife Santuary. Bill Vaughan(?) and his Aboriginal assistant Jacky, give educational talks to visitors. Narrated by Terry Dear.

results.title: Australia's new north-west. Pt. 2: The Pilbara-Hamersley region
results.brief_description: This program deals with the pastoral and timber industries in the Pilbara area, the development of iron ore mining at Mount Tom Price and the growth of towns and industries as a result. Narrated by Roger Climpson.

results.title: Australia's New North-West. Pt. 1: The Kimberley
results.brief_description: Part one of a two-part series, this film deals with agricultural and pastoral development in the Kimberley region. It illustrates the results of irrigation on pilot areas and also refers to the Flying Doctor Service, the School of the Air, and stock, crop and pasture improvement. Narrated by Roger Climpson.

results.title: Australia's most expensive tick
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Researchers”.
Extensive research is uncovering a great deal of information about the cattle tick which costs the beef industry of Northern Australia millions of dollars each year.

results.title: Australia's lathes
results.brief_description: Observes how the Australian brand Macson Lathes is able to cut and manipulate metal producing metal products for other industries. Narrated by Ray Chapman.

results.title: Australia's inland sea
results.brief_description: This film received the Amateur Award in the 1951 Jubilee Film Competition. Three young Australians journeyed to Lake Eyre in the early 1950’s when the lake was filled with water from the highlands of Central Queensland.

results.title: Australia's first foreign war: the Waikato
results.creator_credit: Edwin Morrisby, Southern Latitude Films and John Laynton
results.brief_description: This documentary suggests that the Maori Wars of 1863-64, rather than the Sudan War of 1899-1901, were Australia’s first experience of war, by noting New Zealand’s governor, Sir George Grey’s activities in advertising for, and recruiting volunteers from the Australian colonies. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.
